t: Job 32
So*p these three men ceased to answer Job, because he was righteous in his own eyes.
Then*p was kindled the wrath of Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite, of the kindred of Ram: against Job was his wrath kindled, because he justified himself rather than God.
Also*p against his three friends was his wrath kindled, because they had found no answer, and yet had condemned Job.
Now*p Elihu had waited till Job had spoken, because they were elder than he.
When*p Elihu saw that there was no answer in the mouth of these three men, then his wrath was kindled.
And*p Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite answered and said, I am young, and ye are very old; wherefore I was afraid, and durst not shew you mine opinion.
I*p said, Days should speak, and multitude of years should teach wisdom.
But*p there is a spirit in man: and the inspiration of the Almighty giveth them understanding.
Great*p men are not always wise: neither do the aged understand judgment.
Therefore*p I said, Hearken to me; I also will shew mine opinion.
Behold,*p I waited for your words; I gave ear to your reasons, whilst ye searched out what to say.
Yea,*p I attended unto you, and, behold, there was none of you that convinced Job, or that answered his words:
Lest*p ye should say, We have found out wisdom: God thrusteth him down, not man.
Now*p he hath not directed his words against me: neither will I answer him with your speeches.
They*p were amazed, they answered no more: they left off speaking.
When*p I had waited, (for they spake not, but stood still, and answered no more;)
I*p said, I will answer also my part, I also will shew mine opinion.
For*p I am full of matter, the spirit within me constraineth me.
Behold,*p my belly is as wine which hath no vent; it is ready to burst like new bottles.
I*p will speak, that I may be refreshed: I will open my lips and answer.
Let*p me not, I pray you, accept any man's person, neither let me give flattering titles unto man.
For*p I know not to give flattering titles; in so doing my maker would soon take me away.
